title: Temporal Aliasing in COVID-19 Vaccine Mortality Data
topic_summary: The COVID-19 vaccine mortality debate is unresolvable due to temporal aliasing between the healthy-vaccinee effect (decaying over 2-3 months) and pandemic waves (recurring every 3-6 months), making them indistinguishable in time-series analysis. Visuals emphasize analogies and diagrams for non-experts.
target_audience: General public interested in public health, with visuals making technical concepts accessible (e.g., radio waves, timelines, traffic lights).

scenes.title: Introduction
scenes.narration_summary: Hook with radio analogy – debate unresolvable due to aliasing like two stations on the same frequency.
animations: FadeIn radio wave icons (blue/red), animate overlap collision

scenes.title: The Core Issue
scenes.narration_summary: Timescales: Healthy-vaccinee decays 2-3 months, waves 3-6 months; overlap causes indistinguishability.
animations: Load CDC wave timeline as background
Animate decay curve (Wikipedia) with clock icons

scenes.title: Why Statistics Fail
scenes.narration_summary: No method (e.g., Cox regression) can separate effects, even with large samples.
animations: Bullet list with calculator/graph icons (Icon Archive)
Animate waves merging despite method attempts

scenes.title: Ambiguous Data
scenes.narration_summary: Residuals hover in ambiguous zone – too big to dismiss, too entangled to confirm.
animations: Simple bar chart with yellow shaded zone (traffic light vector)
Animate data points bouncing with question marks

scenes.title: The Solution
scenes.narration_summary: Identify prolonged quiet periods (≥6 months) where aliasing breaks for true comparisons.
animations: Zoom into highlighted quiet window with green checkmark

scenes.title: Predictions and Future
scenes.narration_summary: Predict ratios →1.0 if artifactual; future vaccines risk permanent aliasing if boosters align with waves.
animations: Calendar icons for booster scheduling, turn red on wave sync

scenes.title: Conclusion
scenes.narration_summary: Aliasing locks the debate unless temporal isolation is used.
animations: FadeIn summary icons (waves, timelines) with final text
